1.content:
My name is Angela Easton. Yeah, I've heard all the jokes. I'm 15 years old.

My friends and I are founding members of the Archaeology Club. James Allen, Stephanie Page, Bill Stewart, and I have a real interest in learning about the ancient world. So it was nothing but good news when our folks agreed to take us to Egypt for our summer vacation. And when they arranged for us to explore an actual dig on our last day.

The site was a temple of Horus, the hawk-headed god of the sky. Learning about these ancient people was why we founded the Archaeology Club.

I think it was Stephanie who found it. It was an iridescent white stone, perfectly round. The base had hieroglyphics. "What does this say?"

I whipped out my hieroglyphics cheat sheet. "Looks like it says, 'Gift from the Skies,'" I said. "What do you think it means?"

"Most likely," James said, "they found it inside a meteorite."

Stephanie couldn't resist bringing it out into the open, and we couldn't resist following her.

When the sunlight touched the rock, my field of vision was filled with iridescent white light. It was the most beautiful thing I had ever seen.

Later, a college student asked us, "What was the best thing about the day for you?"

"Definitely the Gift from the Skies," I replied. "I've never seen anything like it."

"Neither have I. What do you suppose that field was?"

"What field?"

"The field projected onto you and your friends by that rock."

It had seemed harmless enough, but now we wondered what we were dealing with.
1.title: How We Took Wing

11.content:
We were fine for the trip home, but something seemed to happen after a couple of days.

I felt this dull ache in my bones. I couldn't figure out why.

As the day went on, another weird thing caught my attention: Electronics didn't seem to work right in my presence anymore. The TV, the phone, computers, tablets: it all quit working when I was in the room. And, if I was in the room with it long enough, I would start feeling sick.

Mom and Dad couldn't get me in to see a doctor right away, but we could clear the electronics out of my room. Mom also seized the opportunity to declare that we'd be eating in the dining room until I was feeling better.

As I sat down to supper, I winced as I sat back in my chair. "What's wrong, honey?" Mom asked.

"My back hurts."

"Worse than the rest?"

I nodded.

"Let's have a look."

I lifted my T-shirt, and Mom gasped.

I went over to the mirror, and it was my turn to gasp.

There were two ridges on my back, over my shoulder blades.
11.title: Back at Home

111.content:
"What's happening to me?" I asked.

"I don't know, baby," Mom replied. "I've never seen anything like this before."

"To hell with the appointment," Dad said, "we're going to the ER."

******************************


The ER was fairly busy, but not so busy that you couldn't spot a familiar face. Or, in this case, three of them: the rest of the Archaeology Club was there. And it didn't take long to figure out that they were going through the same thing I was.

When I finally got in to see a doctor, he ordered X-rays. A nurse brought me to the radiology department, and I stood where the tech told me.

Now, I'd had X-rays before, so I figured I should be just fine. Once the rays hit me, though, I immediately threw up.

The ER doctor was completely baffled, and the fact that they couldn't hook me up to monitors didn't help. In the end, I was admitted for observation, which, in my case, meant that the nurses actually had to get up and check on me themselves. James, Stephanie, and Bill were also checked in. Presumably, their folks stayed with them, as well.

******************************


I woke up in the middle of the night, with the worst pain I had ever felt. The nurse gave me something for it, but my pain washed over it like a tsunami hitting a sand castle. The pain came in waves: Mom would say later that, if she had just my screams to go by, and if she didn't know better, she would've sworn I was giving birth. With each wave of pain, I could feel the skin on my back tightening. The nurses tried, but, with four patients having the same problem, there was no way they could be with everybody.

Finally, there came the absolute worst of the pain. I felt my back open up in two places, and I heard my hospital gown tearing. With that, the pain stopped, and I might have let the sedative do its work if Mom hadn't said, "Oh my God!"

"What?"

She touched me, but not in a place I'd ever felt anything before, and I turned to look.

That's when I saw the wings growing out of my back.

Wings covered in iridescent white feathers.

And the first words out of my mouth were "Gift from the Skies."
111.title: What's Happening?

1111.content:
By the time I explained what I meant to my folks, the others had figured out the connection. The doctors might not have been so easily convinced, but they couldn't deny that what had happened was not normal circumstances.

A doctor gathered us and our families in a conference room. "Why don't you four turn your chairs around," he said to us, "see if that's easier for you?"

Mom always lectured me that sitting that way was bad for my back, and now a doctor was telling me to do it.

"Now, I won't pretend to understand what has happened to you four," he said, "but we can explain the other symptoms you presented when you were admitted."

He lit a box with contrasting X-rays. "Your bones are now hollow, like a bird's. If you were to stand on a scale, you would find that you actually weigh less than you did before. I recommend caution on your part, however: hollow bones are fragile bones.

"As for the disruption of electronics in your vicinity, it appears each of you is now generating a magnetic field. The reason for this field is unknown. You're not going to stick to the refrigerator door, but I'm afraid you're off social media for the foreseeable future."

As we left the conference room, Stephanie pulled us aside. "Follow me," she said.

We followed her up back staircases until we reached the roof. "What did you bring us up here for?" Bill asked.

"Do you mean to tell me," she asked, "that the three of you can grow wings, and not even consider whether you can fly?"
1111.title: The Next Morning

11111.content:
Stephanie was always the adventurous one of the group, having been a bit of an adrenaline junkie when she was a kid. So it came as no surprise to us when she stepped out onto the ledge. James tried to talk her down, but Stephanie was having none of it. “Come on guys, we have wings, shouldn’t we try and use them?”

Before any of us could stop her, Stephanie jumped off the roof and fell out of sight. Fearing the worst, we all ran to the edge expecting to see Stephanie’s body on the pavement below. Instead, we were greeted by the sight of her flying up from below.
Once she was level with us, she just hovered there. Looking at Stephanie, Bill said, “I know you’re a little crazy, Steph, but that was insane even for you.”

“Oh relax, I knew nothing was going to happen.” Flapping her wings, Stephanie said, “Its almost as if my brain knew how to use the wings.”

That was all I needed to hear. I jumped off the ledge as well. I fell about 10 feet before my wings started flapping. Stephanie was right, it was as if we’d had wings all our lives. Seeing the two of us flying around, James and Bill reluctantly joined us.

We flew around the building a couple of times before we saw our parents on the roof with a handful of security guards. Turning to the others, I said, “I think our fun is over. We should probably come in for a landing.”

“Seriously?” sighing, Bill said, “I was just getting the hang of this.”

Despite his resistance, Bill followed the rest of us as we came in for a landing 20 feet from the others on the roof. As Mom walked up to me, I said, “Did you see that, Mom? I was actually flying!”

Taking a look at the four of us, my mom said ______.
11111.title: Learning to Fly

111112.content:
"What were you thinking? Did you think at all? The doctor told you your bones are fragile, and this is what you do."

When you do something potentially stupid, Mom takes the "potentially" part right out. I felt like a four-year-old again, caught with my hand in the cookie jar. I hung my head. I even wrapped my wings around me, as if they had the power to protect me.

"Angela? Where did you go?"

I lifted my head, puzzled by her reaction.

Mom was looking everywhere. "She was standing right here. Where did she go?"

"I'm right here, Mom," I said. "What are you talking about?" I let my wings relax.

Everybody was baffled, not just Mom. "Angela," James said, "we couldn't see you. None of us could."

"Camouflage," the doctor said. "Many birds can blend in with their surroundings. Angela seems to have done something similar." He approached us. "I must say, I am impressed. I didn't think you would be able to fly. I thought that, even with hollow bones, you weighed too much for shoulder-mounted wings to lift. Perhaps this is what your magnetic field is for."

I relaxed a little. "How did you know where to find us?"

"When people jump off the roof," Mom said, "it draws attention. When those peopledon't fall, and, instead, fly around, it draws even more attention. And when those people are wearing hospital gowns, so that all those people looking up can see your underwear,... "

I almost wrapped myself in my wings again.

"Inside," Mom said. "Angela, I'd like to get some measurements, so I can figure something out for you to wear. Try to resist the urge to nearly commit suicide while I'm doing that."
111112.title: That Was Reckless

1111121.content:
Mom didn't take long to go from "Holy crap, my daughter has wings" to "My daughter has wings, how can I help her?" She got a tape measure and measured how far apart my wings were, their circumference as they came out of my back, and their width at the widest part of the wing.

Once she was satisfied with my measurements, she made some alterations to a blouse. "Alright, Angela," she said, "let's try this."

Working slowly, she got the new holes lined up with my wings, then pulled it over them. Once it was on my back, I put my arms through the arm holes, then buttoned up. From the front, it looked alright. From the back, the wing holes let the breezes in. "It needs work," Mom said, "but I've got a rough idea what you'll need. I'll have something better when you're discharged."

"Thanks, Mom."

"So," she asked, "what was it like?"

"What was what like?"

"Flying, of course. I used to have dreams of flying when I was a little girl. What's the real thing like?"

"It was incredible. It felt as natural and normal as breathing. Good thing, since I can't very well ride the bus anymore. But I thought you were mad at me for flying."

"I wasn't mad, dear, I was worried. I was thinking of all the things that could have gone wrong. Once I calmed down, I could be happy for you."

"Both at once, huh?"

"It's called being a mother. One day, you'll see for yourself."
1111121.title: Creative Clothing Design

11111211.content:
We were discharged the next day. Turns out having wings doesn't meet anybody's definition of being sick.

True to her word, Mom had a blouse ready for me. The back had a hem around the base of each wing, and zippers to close it up once it was on. "Good idea, Mom," I said.

"Your friends' parents said the same thing," she replied, "when I showed them."

We gathered outside our rooms. "It's going to feel good to be out of here," Stephanie said, "and start the new normal."

"'Normal' is going to have to wait," her father said. "There are reporters gathered outside. How are we going to get you out of here?"

"I've got an idea," I said. I wrapped my wings around myself. Walking, I asked, "How does it look?"

"There's a bit of a ripple," Dad replied. "If they don't know what to look for, it might just work. Good thing the hospital waived the requirement that you ride out in wheelchairs."

The plan was simple: Our parents would walk out with us, but we would be camouflaged. With the reporters focused on the hospital, our folks would go to their cars, and we would walk to a clear spot behind the hubbub. Then, we'd fly away home.

Maybe it was because it was so simple, but the plan went off without a hitch. One flap was all we needed to go 50 feet into the air, and another flap had us a block away in less than a second. Needless to say, we beat our folks home.
11111211.title: Checking Out

111112111.content:
It came as no surprise that the media was drawn to all of us: it’s not every day that a bunch of kids gain the ability to fly. Two days had passed since we were discharged from the hospital, and they’d been camped out in front of our houses since then.

It really made everything easier having our houses next to each other; James and I lived next to each other while Bill and Stephanie lived behind us. Our backyards were surrounded by trees, so we could hang out without fear of the press seeing us. It was a welcome relief for me, especially after being harassed by them while I went grocery shopping with my mom.

The four of us were sitting inside a treehouse that we’d built in the middle of the yard. “My folks are thinking of taking me camping at Mystic Pines next weekend.” Looking at everyone, Bill said, “You guys can come along if you want; plenty of room to fly around.”

“I don’t know. I’m not sure my moms are too keen on me going away again anytime soon.” Sighing, Stephanie said, “After all, I returned from the last trip with wings.”

“Really, Steph, you’re going to let that stop you?” Scoffing, James said, “You jumped off of a building to see if you could fly, now you’re worried about going camping?”

“I’m not sure it’s a good idea either.” Sighing, I said, “With the reporters following us everywhere we go, I doubt they’ll let us go camping without them knowing.”

“What do you guys suggest then?” pausing, Bill looked at us and said, “Ever since we left the hospital, I’ve been getting this uncontrollable urge to fly.”

I’d been feeling the same urges too, and I’m sure James and Stephanie were feeling them as well. “Why don’t we try flying in that old warehouse down by the harbor?” looking at everyone, I said, “We can practice flying in tight quarters there; especially with all the boxes and machinery that’s sitting there.”

“I suppose that’s a better idea.” Looking at me, Bill said, “Now that I think of it, some hunter up at the park might mistake us for birds and try to take a shot at us.”

“Okay then, it’s settled. We’ll go to the…”

I was interrupted by the familiar sound of a drone outside. It came into view through one of the windows; only to suddenly drop when it got too close to us. Thank you, electromagnetic field! Seeing that, James said, “I guess that’s our cue to leave.” Getting up, he said, “I’ll see you guys later.”

With that, the four of us climbed out of the treehouse and returned to our respective houses.
111112111.title: Dealing with the Media

1111121111.content:
"And where do you think you're going, young lady?" Mom asked me.

"That abandoned warehouse by the harbor," I replied, hoping my casual tone would camouflage my unusual destination.

"And why," she pressed, "would you think I'd allow that?"

I shook my head. "It's hard to explain."

"How can you tell? You haven't tried yet."

I sighed. She had a point. "I need to fly."

"You haven't had wings for a week."

"But I still need it. It... it feels like I'm being forced to sit in a chair, all the time. Or like my wings are tied up. I need to fly."

Mom thought about what I'd said. "The others?"

"They'll be there. They need it, too."

"Step into the other room. I need to make some calls."

After a few minutes, she called me in. "We can keep attention on us for a little bit. Do your thing. We're going to have to figure out a long-term solution for this. For now, wait until I change clothes."

Mom went into her bedroom, and came out dressed like a refugee from the People of Wal-Mart site. "What I'm willing to do for you."

"Thanks, Mom." I wrapped my wings around myself.

Mom shivered. "I will never get used to that."

The plan was fairly simple: Our moms, dressed like white trash, marched into the middle of the street and began arguing loudly and passionately about nothing at all. Meanwhile, the four of us walked, camouflaged, away from the camped-out reporters.
1111121111.title: Continue

choices: I tell mom about the birds.
11111211111.content:
The abandoned warehouse was huge with high ceilings, perfect for us to spread our wings and fly. Of course, Stephanie was the first to take off and fly around, giggling with delight. We all soon joined her, glad to be given a delightful surprise. Other birds flew in to the sound of our fun and joined us in flying around the cavernous space.

"I think they understand us." Giggling, I said.

One bird chirped and we heard, *Play... Fun!*

"They do understand us, and we understand them!" Surprised, James chuckled. "Let me try..."

He was about to chirp but froze as he saw a cat walking into the warehouse, and chirped, "Danger!"

The birds, understanding the warning, scattered in time to avoid the leaping cat, trying to catch an easy meal. Bill dived down at the cat, giving an angry screech that sent the startled cat running with its fur puffed up. *Go catch some fish, tabby.* Chirping, he called.

Two birds flew down, landing onto Bill's shoulders with a chirp, *Thank you.*

Bill blushed slightly, as one of the birds was female. *You are welcome.*

I giggled at the sight, then turned as all of the birds chirped out, *Danger!*

Stephanie flew to a window and gasped before chirping, *It's a news van!*

Bill flapped his wings once, sending himself to the high ceiling, where he landed on a large support beam and covered himself with his wings, vanishing from sight. We all followed suit, while the birds responded to our apparent fear and attacked the reporters as they entered the warehouse. With well over thirty birds of all sizes dive-bombing them, the reporters made a hasty retreat and drove away.

*All clear* was soon after called, and we spread our wings, becoming visible again. Seeing the birds celebrating their victory in protecting their territory, I could not help smile. "I think we just made a lot of new friends." I then chirped out, *Thank you.*

The birds responded with, *Play!... Fun!*

We all laughed at that and continued with our fun until it was time for us to return home.
11111211111.title: Learning a new language.

111112111111.content:
Upon returning home under the cover of the failing light of the day, I told Mom of our adventure inside the abandoned warehouse. "It was incredible..." In a dreamy voice, I said. "We can talk to birds, and they can talk to us." I sighed, smiling. "We warned them of a cat sneaking up on us, and they warned us of a news van coming our way. They even chased them away for us"

"You can talk to birds now?" Her eyes dancing, Mom asked. "Is it a difficult language?'

"I don't know, really." Shrugging, I said. "It seemed to come as naturally as flying."

Mom was silent for a moment before she softly asked, "Can you teach me the language?"

"You want to talk to birds?" Surprised, I asked.

Mom shook her head. "I want to know what you are saying when you decide to use the language around me." Serious, she replied. She then blushed. "It's also a childhood dream of mine... can you teach me?"

"I guess I could try." Bemused, I said. I then chirped something and said, "That means 'hello'."

Mom walked to her caged parakeet, whom she had called Suzie, and chirped to it as I had showed her. Suzie sharply turned in her direction before chirping back. Mom then turned to me. "What did she say?"

I giggled. "She said, 'It talks!'" I then giggled again and turned to the parakeet before chirping, *She wants to learn to talk to you.*

Suzie was quiet for a moment then gave a series of rapid chirps, she was laughing. Mom seemed to sense it and gave Suzie an unimpressed look. "Oh, you think I can't learn a new language, do you?" She turned to me. "Teach me..."

I giggled again. "Make some tea, Mom." Bemused, I said. "It's going to be a long night."
111112111111.title: Bird Talk.

1111121111112.content:
I had taken to speaking fluent bird like a shot, but Mom was a slower study. She was fine with *Hello* and *How are you?*, but other, more complex chirps were mangled. *It's a lovely day* came out sounding more like *I would like to mate with the sun.*

We both got a big shock, though, when Mom chirped, *Suzie is a pretty girl.*

Suzie responded by looking at me and chirping, *Who is Suzie?*

*That's what she calls you,* I replied.

*But I'm a male.*

"I didn't get that," Mom said.

"Mom," I said, "'Suzie' is a boy."

"Oh, dear," Mom said, then chirped, *You are a desirable mate.*

In response to his quizzical look, I chirped, *She only meant to say that you are a good-looking bird.*

Deciding she'd embarrassed herself sufficiently in her pet's eyes, Mom said, "Ask what he thinks of the name Scottie."

I did, and got a pleasant response. "He likes it. It's very close to his own chirp-name."

When Dad got home, he was puzzled by why Mom and I were chirping at the family pet. He declined offers to teach him the language.
1111121111112.title: Learning bird talk is difficult.

choices: I talk to the crows that night.
11111211111121.content:
After Mom had left to call it a night, I turned to Scottie as he asked, *How did you get wings?*

I explained how we came to have wings, and learned how to fly, then talk to birds, to which Scottie seemed trapped between bemusement and worry. *There is a wise old owl who checks up on me from time to time.* Serious, he chirped. *Seek him out at the old oak. He may have the answers you and your friends seek.*

I smiled at Scottie. *Thank you.* Quietly, I chirped back.

After covering Scottie's cage for the night, I looked out the window at the old oak on the empty lot down the street. Knotting my jaws, I decided to sneak out and visit the wise old owl. Sneaking out of the house was the hard part, as Mom had become a light sleeper since the media started camping out outside of our house. Fortunately, Scottie was nice enough to remain silent as I unlocked the door and crept out. "So far, so good..." Wrapping my wings around me, I muttered. "Now to get to the old oak tree..."

I walked quickly, but quietly, past the reporters, as they sipped on coffee and talked among themselves about how to get an interview with me or the others. I was grateful to be able to get past them without notice, and cautiously approached the old oak. It was the tallest tree in the neighborhood, I would dare say it was big and strong enough to hold my friends and me easily on its thick high branches. Upon reaching it, I met the old owl. He was far larger than I could have imagined, near the size of an eagle. As I unfolded my wings before him, I felt a twinge of fear, knowing the great owl was a bird of prey...

*Why have you come?* Sternly, the owl chirped.

*Scottie said you may have answers I seek.* Nervously, I chirped back.

The owl looked at me for a moment then chirped, *The Gift from the Skies is not given lightly, or on a whim. You and your friends were chosen.*

*Chosen?!* Taken back, I chirped. *How... Why?*

The old owl gave me what looked like a bemused smile. *You and your flock are well known in these woods, and in the woods beyond.* Cryptically, he chirped back. *To get the answers you seek, you must first go to the crows. They are who first nominated your flock for the Gift.*

With that, he spread his wings and flew away into the night to hunt. I sighed, feeling as if the answers I got only raised more questions. My friends and I have been known to feed the crows and other birds during the winter, when food was scarce, for years. We had also fought to protect the bird's habitats from a sleazy land developer who wanted to put up a mall in our back yard, and won. Still, it was nothing spectacular to my mind, just doing the right thing.

"I wonder what the crows will have to say." Curious, I muttered.
11111211111121.title: An Interview?

choices: The next morning, meeting with the crow.
111112111111212.content:
I decided to wait until morning, so my friends and I could talk to the crows together, as one flock, as the old owl put it. Returning home was not a challenge, as most of the reporters had already settled in for the night inside their news vans. Upon entering the house, I was confronted by Dad, who did not seem very pleased at all that I had snuck out.

"Needed a night flight, did you?" Softly, he inquired. "Give me one reason I should not ground you here on the spot."

I folded my arms. "I kept quiet about you sneaking away for a night out with the boys here and there." Whispering, I countered. "It cost me getting grounded by Mom more than once."

Dad sighed. "Somehow, I knew you would play that card at some point." Bemused, he whispered. "Alright, but this makes us even. Where did you go?"

"To see the old owl down the street." Honestly, I replied. "It seems we were chosen for this Gift from the Skies, and it was the crows who first nominated us."

Dad raised a single eyebrow. "So you are planning to talk to the crows tomorrow, to find out how and why..." He shook his head. "There is a crow that comes to the attic every morning. You can arrange a meeting with them then."

"Arrange a meeting?" Curious, I asked.

"Crows are very intelligent birds, but they are slow to trust." Serious, Dad said. "It's better to ask for a meeting with them rather than just showing up out of the blue." He sighed. "You said it yourself, the old owl first demanded why you had come to him before he allowed you to speak."

"I guess it's a start." Shrugging, I said. "Should I call my friends over..."

Dad shook his head. "If you go as a group, the crow may never enter the attic." Serious, he said. "Go alone, and arrange the meeting for you all." He then tussled my hair. "Get some sleep, before Mom finds you up and about, and gets worried."

I nodded and went back to bed. I no longer slept in a regular bed as I used to. It was now a large nest I had made myself, out of soft blankets and pillows. I was not sure how I knew how to make it, but it was more comfortable than anything I had ever slept in before. Once I got in, I folded my wings and soon fell asleep.
111112111111212.title: I wait till morning.

choices: At noon, we fly with the crows.
1111121111112121.content:
The following morning, I slowly walked up into the attic, with my heart in my throat. I was excited, but also fearful, as the attic was fairly small. I don't know if it was claustrophobia or something else that was fueling my uneasiness, but the crow was there, just as Dad said he would be.

*The owl said you have questions.* Courtly, the crow cawed. *Ask, youngling.*

I took a breath, quickly gathering my thoughts and chirped, *The owl told me that The Gift From the Skies is not given lightly... why us...?*

*There were others just as worthy.* Serious, the crow cawed back. *However, you and your flock have done more for our forest, and the forests beyond, than you may imagine.*

*I don't understand.* Teary eyed, I chirped. *We are grateful for the gift, but confused.*

The crow gave a cry that could only be a laugh. *Your migration to save the great woods moved other flocks to do the same.* Kindly, he cawed. *Because your flock acted, the woods from here to the great waters have been deemed protected.* Seeing, my confused look, he added, *A few within our flock have lived with humans and learned to read.*

This floored me in more ways than one. Crows were far more intelligent that Dad or anyone could have imagined... *We are honored by your nomination.* Bowing, I chirped.

The crow bowed back and cawed, *The honor is ours. Fly with us when the sun reaches its peak, and we will show you to those who made the final decision.*

With that, the crow flew off, leaving me with a deeper sense and appreciation and understanding of all the birds around me. "I need to call my flock..."
1111121111112121.title: The wisdom of the crow.

choices: Stranger come to talk to me.
11111211111121212.content:
After a lengthy conversation with Mom and Dad, barely avoiding getting grounded, James, Steph, Bill, and I took to the skies, under the cover of a large flock of crows. *Follow* They all cawed.

Follow them, we did, over what seemed like miles, until we reached Lake Hope, a large man-made lake in the middle of the Cherokee Bird Sanctuary. There, we all landed in a small clearing, where we were greeted by a number of birds that were thought to be long extinct including the Kiwi, the Mysterious Starling, and the Pagan Reed-Warbler. They all greeted us with friendly chirps, before one crow, the one I had spoken to, explained their visit.

*They are grateful for their gift.* Serious, the crow cawed. *They are also curious why they were chosen over so many others.*

*The answer is as clear as the skies over the clouds.* A powerful chirp replied.

Startled, we all turned and looked up over the lake to behold a sight none of us had ever expected to see... "A Thunderbird..." Awestruck, I whispered. "A real Thunderbird..."

*There are small pockets of forests around the world where we, thought dead, still survive.* Serious, the Thunderbird chirped. *Your efforts saved them all, as it had started a trend many around the world had followed. This is why you were chosen.*

*Who made the final decision?* Curious, Stephanie chirped. *We wish to thank him or her.*

*It is us thanking you, younglings.* Kindly, the Thunderbird chirped in return. *It was Horus himself who made the final decision.* He let out a chirp that could only have been a laugh. *It was no accident that all your parents gained the wealth needed to take you to Egypt.*

We were all left stunned and humbled as the birds around us began to chirp cheers and words of gratitude, before flying about in a form of celebration. The Thunderbird lit up the sky with a cloud cover and lightning display. Berries and nuts were brought to us as the celebration in our honor continued on, until the Thunderbird signaled it was time for us to return home.

*Now you understand.* Calmly, the crow chirped. *You and your friends saved many birds from extinction. That deed is worthy of the Gift from the Skies.*

Upon returning home, under the cover of the setting sun, I told Mom and Dad what had happened. "I suggest we all keep these forests, and what they contain, a carefully guarded secret." Serious, Dad said. "The birds you had described have been hunted to extinction, and there are those who would hunt them down due to their extreme worth, being so rare."

"The secret will not be told by me." Also serious, I said.

"Not a word of it." With a firm nod, Mom added.

"Good." Satisfied, Dad said. "The only question left is, what now?"
11111211111121212.title: At noon, we fly with the crows.

111112111111212121.content:
As I went to bed that night, I did not think anything more could ever surprise me... I was wrong...

Soft, spark-like sounds woke me from my sleep, and I immediately noticed that my room was lit by an unknown light. I slowly got up from my bed, only to find that it had somehow been charred and was smoking! Frightened, I turned to a mirror to find that my eyes had turned a gold within gold color and my wings were sending out small sparks of fire! "What the hell..."

Mom and Dad were wrenched from their slumber by my panicked scream. Dad raced up the stairs to my bedroom and threw open the door, only to be hit with a powerful wave of hot air that nearly threw him back down the stairs. Fortunately, he managed to grab a hold of my door frame, and pushed himself inside. Nothing was on fire in my room, it was just very hot. He found me with my back turned to him, completely naked, with an aura of fire surrounding me. "Angela!"

Shivering in fear, I turned to Dad, before blushing profusely, as I realized I had no clothes on. Almost on instinct, I wrapped myself with my wings and became invisible. The moment I did that, the room almost instantly cooled, except I could see the heat still radiating from my body.

Dad was one who liked to always be prepared for anything. That said, he grabbed a fire blanket from my closet and wrapped it around my body. "Calm down, sweetie." Firmly but kindly, he said. "Daddy's here, he is not going to let anything hurt his little angel.."

Slowly, hesitantly, I folded my wings behind my back, with the blanket still around me, and became visible, though still very much shaken. "Daddy,... what is happening to me?"

Dad was silent for a long time before he walked over to my computer and typed something in before motioning to the screen. "I have been researching the Gift of the Skies." Softly, he said. "There are four birds of great power in mythologies all around the world. The Phoenix, the Thunderbird, the Firebird and the Waterbird."

"What- What does this have to do with..." Confused, I asked. Then I saw the screen...

Noting my shocked expression, Dad continued. "There is a legend that states if all four birds were to unite, the Earth would be restored to balance." He sighed. "We humans have made a mess of things, drove several species of animals to extinction and worse..."

"The Gift of the Skies..." Softly, I said. "I'm becoming the Phoenix..."

The image on the screen was of a beautiful silver winged girl with golden eyes in an aura of fire. What surprised me more was that the girl was a mirror image of myself!

"I'm beginning to suspect there was more than your kindness to birds that led you to this gift." Serious, dad said. "You said you had met a real Thunderbird."

I nodded, tears falling. "What I didn't mention was that the Thunderbird looked very old..."

Dad sighed. "He's likely the last of his kind, which means..."

I gulped. "Which means one of my friends is likely the next Thunderbird..."
111112111111212121.title: I discover new abilities.
